author: kelemeno
content: Yes, but with zk proofs you can commit the L2's state root there, and that contains everything else (the tx data can also be there as calldata or data blob after 4844). So the tx itself does not need to go through L1. But I think this is well established in the links I sent

author: kelemeno
content: the big guy  also describes it https://vitalik.ca/general/2022/09/17/layer_3.html

author: plasmapower
content: I don't think that's exclusive to zk proofs, optimistic rollups commit to the L2 state root on L1 too, though zk rollups do commit faster. But to get back to your original censorship question, it seems to me like if you can force the chain to advance you can force it to make the L2 state root commitment on L1, which would then let you make the L2<->L2 message.

author: kelemeno
content: Yes, so what I'm looking for is if the receiving L2 sequencer set censors (which might be the case for small L2s), then you can force it through L1, but that will be expensive. And I think that via a DA layer, you can force the rollup to look for txs on the DA layer, and receive them. This is what Celestia does to some extent.
